The measures come into effect at 12:01 a.m. Monday, and restrict travel to those who live or work in Ontario, are entering the province for health-care reasons, Indigenous Treaty Rights, child care or custody matters, transporting goods, or are travelling through the province to go somewhere else.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E  \u003Cul\u003E   \u003Cli\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.cbc.ca\u002Fnews\u002Fcanada\u002Fottawa\u002Fottawa-gatineau-interprovincial-border-closed-monday-april-19-1.5990961\"\u003ECheckpoints to return to Ottawa-Gatineau border Monday\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E  \u003C\u002Ful\u003E  \u003Cp\u003EOfficers will be stationed 24\u002F7 on the Ontario side of the Champlain, Portage, Chaudière and Macdonald-Cartier bridges as well as the docks for the Quyon and the Bourbonnais ferries, the Ottawa Police Service wrote in a release Sunday afternoon.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E  \u003Cp\u003EOfficers will also be stationed at the Alexandra Bridge, as the provincial order also applies to pedestrians and cyclists, according to the statement. \u003C\u002Fp\u003E    \u003Cblockquote class=\"pullquote\"\u003E  We have to trust that people are going to be honest.​​​​​​  \u003Ccite class=\"pullquote-source\"\u003E- Inspector Michel Marin\u003C\u002Fcite\u003E \u003C\u002Fblockquote\u003E    \u003Cp\u003EPolice said officers will only stop private passenger vehicles and not commercial ones, which are exempt from the provincial order.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E  \u003Cp\u003E\"We're going to ask for a reason why you're going into Ontario and then you'll be sent on your way,\" said Inspector Michel Marin. \"If we're asking [drivers] to turn around for whatever reasons, we'll be keeping tabs on that.\"\u003C\u002Fp\u003E  \u003Ch2\u003ENo written documentation needed\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E  \u003Cp\u003EHe said officers don't have plans to issue fines to people who may re-offend.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E  \u003Cp\u003E\"Most people we're dealing with have the good commonsense approach to why we're doing this and the general public generally tends to be very co-operative and we're not anticipating any major issues on those bridges,\" said Marin.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E  \u003Cp\u003EHe said officers won't require written documentation to show someone has an essential reason for entering Ontario. \u003C\u002Fp\u003E  \u003Cp\u003E\"We have to trust that people are going to be honest,\" he said.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E  \u003Cp\u003E\"There are quite a number of people that live on the Gatineau, Que., side that come to Ottawa every day to work and a lot of those folks are essential workers ... We'll simply allow them through.\"\u003C\u002Fp\u003E  \u003Cp\u003EOntario Provincial Police will also have officers stationed on interprovincial roadways, including highways 401, 417, and 17, and the interprovincial bridge at John Street in Hawkesbury, Ont.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E  \u003Cp\u003E \u003C\u002Fp\u003E","keywords":[{"entities":[{"name":"Government and politics\u002FLaw enforcement class="detailBodyContainer"><div class="detailMainCol sclt-storycontent"><span class="detail-link-label sclt-storySectionLink"><a class="" href="/news/canada/ottawa"><span title="">Ottawa</span></a></span><h1 class="detailHeadline" lang="en">Police will begin stopping Ontario-bound passenger vehicles Monday</h1><div class="detailSummary">Ottawa police say they will have officers stationed at all five interprovincial bridges and two ferries linking the Outaouais and Ottawa.</div><div class="share"><div class="viafoura"><h2 class="a11y">Social Sharing</h2><div class="vf-widget vf-share-bar-horizontal" data-widget="sharebar" data-button-view="false" data-url="https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/ottawa/ottawa-police-interprovincial-crossings-covid-19-1.5992615" data-show-labels="true" data-show-counters="false" data-show-total="false"></div></div></div><h2 class="deck" lang="en">Officers will require only a verbal reason why someone needs to enter province, OPS says</h2><div class="byline"><div class="bylineDetails">CBC News<!-- --> <span class="bullet"> · </span><time class="timeStamp" datetime="2021-04-18T22:10:22.317Z">Posted: Apr 18, 2021 5:48 PM ET | Last Updated: April 18</time></div></div><div class="storyWrapper"><figure class="imageMedia leadmedia-story full"><div class="placeholder"><div class="placeholderImage" style="padding-bottom:56.25%"></div><img loading="lazy" alt="" srcset="" sizes="" src="https://i.cbc.ca/1.5519050.1585844165!/fileImage/httpImage/image.jpeg_gen/derivatives/16x9_780/covid-coronavirus-ottawa-gatineau-ontario-quebec-border-rules-bridge.jpeg"/></div><figcaption class="image-caption">A police checkpoint on the Macdonald-Cartier Bridge between Ottawa and Gatineau, Que., on April 1, 2020. Ottawa police say they'll have officers set up 24/7 at all vehicle crossings between the Outaouais and Ottawa starting at 12:01 a.m. Monday.<!-- --> <!-- -->(Emilien Juteau/CBC)</figcaption></figure><div class="story"><span><p>Ottawa police say they will have officers stationed at all five interprovincial bridges and two ferries linking the Outaouais and Ottawa.</p>  <p>It's all in response to a <a href="https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/ottawa/ottawa-gatineau-interprovincial-border-closed-monday-april-19-1.5990961">provincial order restricting only essential travel into Ontario</a> from neighbouring provinces. The measures come into effect at 12:01 a.m. Monday, and restrict travel to those who live or work in Ontario, are entering the province for health-care reasons, Indigenous Treaty Rights, child care or custody matters, transporting goods, or are travelling through the province to go somewhere else.</p><section id="inread-wrapper-id-69618724"></section>  <ul>   <li><a href="https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/ottawa/ottawa-gatineau-interprovincial-border-closed-monday-april-19-1.5990961">Checkpoints to return to Ottawa-Gatineau border Monday</a></li>  </ul>  <p>Officers will be stationed 24/7 on the Ontario side of the Champlain, Portage, Chaudière and Macdonald-Cartier bridges as well as the docks for the Quyon and the Bourbonnais ferries, the Ottawa Police Service wrote in a release Sunday afternoon.</p>  <p>Officers will also be stationed at the Alexandra Bridge, as the provincial order also applies to pedestrians and cyclists, according to the statement. </p> c4.599,0,8.8,3.201,8.8,10.6c0,13.6-7,20-17.6,21.801V29.759z"></path></g></g></svg></span><cite class="pullquote-source">- Inspector Michel Marin</cite></span></blockquote>    <p>Police said officers will only stop private passenger vehicles and not commercial ones, which are exempt from the provincial order.</p>  <p>"We're going to ask for a reason why you're going into Ontario and then you'll be sent on your way," said Inspector Michel Marin. "If we're asking [drivers] to turn around for whatever reasons, we'll be keeping tabs on that."</p>  <h2>No written documentation needed</h2>  <p>He said officers don't have plans to issue fines to people who may re-offend.</p>  <p>"Most people we're dealing with have the good commonsense approach to why we're doing this and the general public generally tends to be very co-operative and we're not anticipating any major issues on those bridges," said Marin.</p>  <p>He said officers won't require written documentation to show someone has an essential reason for entering Ontario. </p>  <p>"We have to trust that people are going to be honest," he said.</p>  <p>"There are quite a number of people that live on the Gatineau, Que., side that come to Ottawa every day to work and a lot of those folks are essential workers ... We'll simply allow them through."</p>  <p>Ontario Provincial Police will also have officers stationed on interprovincial roadways, including highways 401, 417, and 17, and the interprovincial bridge at John Street in Hawkesbury, Ont.</p>  <p> </p></span></div></div><div class="contentFeedback"><div class="bottomSeparator"><a Now it says that didn't happen","originalheadline":"Ontario said it would investigate horrific deaths in long-term care. Now it says that didn't happen.","deck":"NDP calling on provincial police to investigate cases where seniors died of dehydration","summary":"Nearly one year ago, as the first detailed picture emerged of the true scale of the horror faced by residents of Ontario's long-term care system during the pandemic, a visibly emotional Premier Doug Ford vowed his government would conduct a full investigation. Now it turns out that didn't happen.","byline":"CBC News","highlights":{"highlight":[],"label":"Updated"},"intlinks":[],"extlinks":[],"updatedAt":1620346563977,"publishedAt":1620322437570,"publishedAtVerbal":"May 06, 2021 1:33 PM ET","displayComments":false,"url":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.cbc.ca\u002Fnews\u002Fcanada\u002Ftoronto\u002Fontario-ford-long-term-care-criminal-charges-1.6016274","category":"","flag":"","body":"\u003Cp\u003EThe day before Cathy Parkes's father died, she went to see him through the window of his Pickering, Ont., long-term care home.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E  \u003Cp\u003EPaul Parkes, 86, had been suffering from a urinary tract infection and wasn't getting enough water.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E  \u003Cp\u003EA personal support worker said he wouldn't take fluids. Cathy asked if her father could be sent to hospital. She says the home refused.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E  \u003Cp\u003E\"I saw what he looked like in his casket when we had the viewing and he was a completely different man than what I had seen just weeks before,\" she told CBC News.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E  \u003Cp\u003EParkes died in April of last year, and Cathy dove into advocacy — she says it's been a way to make sure her father's death wasn't in vain, but it's also stopped her from fully grieving. On behalf of about 250 others whose lives have been affected by a death there, she now awaits the results of a police investigation into the Orchard Villa home.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E  \u003Cp\u003E\"We just want the truth,\" she said. \u003C\u002Fp\u003E  \u003Cp\u003E[IMAGE]\u003C\u002Fp\u003E  \u003Ch2\u003E'There's going to be justice', Ford promised\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E  \u003Cp\u003E\"If I had had my father living at home with me and I didn't feed him and I didn't give him water and I didn't give him medication or send him to the hospital, I would be criminally charged,\" she said.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E  \u003Cp\u003E\"So I don't know why when these things to residents of long-term care, we look the other way.\"\u003C\u002Fp\u003E  \u003Cp\u003EThe truth is what the Ontario government had promised one year ago in the wake of a disturbing Canadian Armed Forces report into five of the province's long-term care facilities, whose findings prompted widespread public outcry. \u003C\u002Fp\u003E  \u003Cp\u003ENearly one year ago, as that first detailed picture emerged of the true scale of the horror faced by residents of Ontario's long-term care system during the pandemic, a visibly emotional Premier Doug Ford vowed: \"There's going to be justice.\"\u003C\u002Fp\u003E  \u003Cp\u003EPatients with ulcers with soiled sheets left bed-bound as COVID-19 tore through homes, dehydration, cockroaches and staff moving unit to unit in contaminated gear — those were just some of the unsettling images contained the report.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E  \u003Cp\u003EIn the face of it all, the premier vowed a full investigation, with the details to be turned over to police who could lay criminal charges if warranted.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E  \u003Cp\u003E\"The government has already begun an active investigation,\" the province said in a news release last May. \u003C\u002Fp\u003E  \u003Cp\u003ENow, it turns out, that didn't happen.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E  \u003Cp\u003EDuring a news conference Wednesday, Solicitor General Sylvia Jones told reporters, in response to question by a QP Briefing reporter: \"Investigations would not happen at a provincial level or a ministry level.\"\u003C\u002Fp\u003E  \u003Cp\u003E\"They would be the purview and the responsibility of either the local police departments or in some cases, they would refer it to another division, another police operation.\"\u003C\u002Fp\u003E  \u003Cp\u003EIn its news release announcing an investigation last year, the province said one death had been referred to Office of the Chief Coroner for investigation. \"Specific critical incidents\" in the report were referred to the Ministry of Long-Term Care's inspections branch.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E  \u003Cp\u003E\u003Cem\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EWATCH | Jones answers questions about investigation:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E  \u003Cp\u003E[MEDIA]\u003C\u002Fp\u003E  \u003Cp\u003EIn a statement Thursday, a spokesperson for Jones said it was the deputy solicitor general who provided the report to the coroner's office. \u003C\u002Fp\u003E  \u003Cp\u003E\"Should there be any criminal concerns during a death investigation, the coroner would bring them to the attention of the police. The Office of the Chief Coroner does not have the authority to lay criminal charges,\" said spokesperson Stephen Warner.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E  \u003Cp\u003ESpeaking in the Legislature on Thursday, Minister of Long-Term Care Merrilee Fullerton said homes were subject investigation by individual inspectors.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E  \u003Cp\u003E\"Each home was inspected by two or more inspectors … Had inspectors found potentially criminal conduct, they would have passed that information on to the police.\"\u003C\u002Fp\u003E  \u003Ch2\u003E'They died when all they needed was water and a wipe down'\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E  \u003Cp\u003EIn a letter to Ontario Provincial Police Commissioner Thomas Carrique Thursday, Opposition Leader Andrea Horwath called on the police force to \"evaluate\" whether instances of lack of water and personal care documented by armed forces and the Long-Term Care COVID-19 Commission \"constitute a case for criminal charges.\"\u003C\u002Fp\u003E  \u003Cp\u003E\"As I read of 26 seniors perishing not from COVID-19 but from a lack of water and personal care, my heart broke. I thought we had heard the worst of things, but I was wrong,\" the NDP's Horwath wrote. \"I entrust your force to make a thorough evaluation, and to lay charges where necessary,\" she said.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E  \u003Cp\u003EThe commission, which unveiled its \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.ltccommission-commissionsld.ca\u002Freport\u002Fpdf\u002FOntarios_Long-Term_Care_COVID-19_Commission_Final_Report.pdf\"\u003Efinal 322-page report\u003C\u002Fa\u003E Friday night, said that by the time the armed forces arrived at the homes identified as most in need of attention, \"they found deplorable conditions.\"\u003C\u002Fp\u003E  \u003Cp\u003E\"It was noted by ACCT [augmented civilian care team] that 26 residents died due to dehydration prior to the arrival of the CAF team due to the lack of staff to care for them,\" the report quotes one member as saying.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E  \u003Cp\u003E\"They died when all they needed was 'water and a wipe down.'\"\u003C\u002Fp\u003E  \u003Cp\u003E\u003Cem\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EWATCH | Long-term care minister responds to report:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E  \u003Cp\u003E[MEDIA]\u003C\u002Fp\u003E  \u003Ch2\u003EOPP not currently investigating\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E  \u003Cp\u003EBut as of Thursday, OPP spokesperson Bill Dickson told CBC News he wasn't aware of any ongoing investigations into deaths at nursing homes in the province related to COVID-19.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E  \u003Cp\u003EDurham Regional Police Services spokesperson George Tudos confirmed an investigation is happening in that region but declined a request for an interview.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E  \u003Cp\u003E\"We are reviewing the details of the Ontario's Long-Term Care COVID-9 Commission report released on April 30, 2021 and this remains an ongoing investigation. We don't have anything further to add at this point,\" he said. \u003C\u002Fp\u003E  \u003Cp\u003EParkes says she's been told by police an update should be available next week. What that might be, she hasn't been told.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E  \u003Cp\u003EThe commission concluded Ontario had no plan to protect long-term care residents amid the pandemic, citing chronic underfunding, staffing shortages and poor oversight.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E  \u003Cp\u003E[SIMILAR][SIMILAR][SIMILAR]\u003C\u002Fp\u003E  \u003Cp\u003EThe commissioners also said Dr. David Williams, the province's chief medical officer of health, in particular, was too slow to act on emerging information about COVID-19.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E  \u003Cp\u003EWorkers in the long-term care sector were described making personal protective equipment out of \"pop bottles and plastic bags\" because regular masks were in such short supply.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E  \u003Cp\u003EEarlier Friday, Ford said he welcomed the commission's report, as difficult as it would be to read.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E  \u003Cp\u003E\"What happened in our long-term care homes, it was tragic,\" he said. \"And it was terrible. But most of all, it can never be allowed to happen again.\"\u003C\u002Fp\u003E  \u003Cp\u003E\u003Cem\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EWATCH | Ford calls findings 'gut-wrenching':\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E  \u003Cp\u003E[MEDIA]\u003C\u002Fp\u003E  \u003Cp\u003EFor now, Parkes waits for accountability in her father's death and those of so many others who died in a place where they expected to receive care.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E  \u003Cp\u003EShe's grown tired of the political sound bites, she says, and what she describes a lack of tangible action. \u003C\u002Fp\u003E  \u003Cp\u003E\"If you say you're going to do something and you're crying on television about how it affects you, let's see some action. And that's been the problem all along, a lot of words and no action,\" she said.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E  \u003Cp\u003EUntil then, she says: \"It's a wound that never gets to close.\"\u003C\u002Fp\u003E class="detailBodyContainer"><div class="detailMainCol sclt-storycontent"><span class="detail-link-label sclt-storySectionLink"><a class="" href="/news/canada/toronto"><span title="">Toronto</span></a></span><h1 class="detailHeadline" lang="en">Ontario vowed to investigate horrific deaths in long-term care. Now it says that didn't happen</h1><div class="detailSummary">Nearly one year ago, as the first detailed picture emerged of the true scale of the horror faced by residents of Ontario's long-term care system during the pandemic, a visibly emotional Premier Doug Ford vowed his government would conduct a full investigation. Now it turns out that didn't happen.</div><div class="share"><div class="viafoura"><h2 class="a11y">Social Sharing</h2><div class="vf-widget vf-share-bar-horizontal" data-widget="sharebar" data-button-view="false" data-url="https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/toronto/ontario-ford-long-term-care-criminal-charges-1.6016274" data-show-labels="true" data-show-counters="false" data-show-total="false"></div></div></div><h2 class="deck" lang="en">NDP calling on provincial police to investigate cases where seniors died of dehydration</h2><div class="byline"><div class="bylineDetails"><span class="authorText"><a class="" href="/news/canada/toronto/author/shanifa-nasser-1.3965983">Shanifa Nasser</a></span> <span class="bullet"> · </span>CBC News<!-- --> <span class="bullet"> · </span><time class="timeStamp" datetime="2021-05-07T00:16:03.977Z">Posted: May 06, 2021 1:33 PM ET | Last Updated: May 7</time></div></div><div class="storyWrapper"><figure class="imageMedia leadmedia-story full"><div class="placeholder"><div class="placeholderImage" style="padding-bottom:56.25%"></div><img loading="lazy" alt="" srcset="" sizes="" src="https://i.cbc.ca/1.6016995.1620333531!/cumulusImage/httpImage/image.jpg_gen/derivatives/16x9_780/cathy-parkes.jpg"/></div><figcaption class="image-caption">Cathy Parkes, whose father, Paul Parkes, died of COVID-19 last year while living at Orchard Villa Retirement Community, is pictured near her home in Pickering, Ont., on Thursday.<!-- --> <!-- -->(Evan Mitsui/CBC)</figcaption></figure><div class="story"><span><p>The day before Cathy Parkes's father died, she went to see him through the window of his Pickering, Ont., long-term care home.</p>  <p>Paul Parkes, 86, had been suffering from a urinary tract infection and wasn't getting enough water.</p><section id="inread-wrapper-id-69792577"></section>  <p>A personal support worker said he wouldn't take fluids. Cathy asked if her father could be sent to hospital. She says the home refused.</p>  <p>"I saw what he looked like in his casket when we had the viewing and he was a completely different man than what I had seen just weeks before," she told CBC News.</p>  <p>Parkes died in April of last year, and Cathy dove into advocacy — she says it's been a way to make sure her father's death wasn't in vain, but it's also stopped her from fully grieving. On behalf of about 250 others whose lives have been affected by a death there, she now awaits the results of a police investigation into the Orchard Villa home.</p>  <p>"We just want the truth," she said. </p>  <div><span><figure class="imageMedia image full"><div class="placeholder"><div class="placeholderImage" style="padding-bottom:66.61%"></div><img loading="lazy" alt="" srcset="https://i.cbc.ca/1.5872351.1610582052!/cumulusImage/httpImage/image.jpg_gen/derivatives/original_300/covid-19-camilla-care-ltch-crosses.jpg 300w,https://i.cbc.ca/1.5872351.1610582052!/cumulusImage/httpImage/image.jpg_gen/derivatives/original_460/covid-19-camilla-care-ltch-crosses.jpg representing residents who died of COVID-19 are pictured on the lawn of Camilla Care Community, in Mississauga, Ont., on Jan. 13, 2020.<!-- --> <!-- -->(Evan Mitsui/CBC)</figcaption></figure></span></div>  <h2>'There's going to be justice', Ford promised</h2>  <p>"If I had had my father living at home with me and I didn't feed him and I didn't give him water and I didn't give him medication or send him to the hospital, I would be criminally charged," she said.</p>  <p>"So I don't know why when these things to residents of long-term care, we look the other way."</p>  <p>The truth is what the Ontario government had promised one year ago in the wake of a disturbing Canadian Armed Forces report into five of the province's long-term care facilities, whose findings prompted widespread public outcry. </p>  <p>Nearly one year ago, as that first detailed picture emerged of the true scale of the horror faced by residents of Ontario's long-term care system during the pandemic, a visibly emotional Premier Doug Ford vowed: "There's going to be justice."</p>  <p>Patients with ulcers with soiled sheets left bed-bound as COVID-19 tore through homes, dehydration, cockroaches and staff moving unit to unit in contaminated gear — those were just some of the unsettling images contained the report.</p>  <p>In the face of it all, the premier vowed a full investigation, with the details to be turned over to police who could lay criminal charges if warranted.</p>  <p>"The government has already begun an active investigation," the province said in a news release last May. </p>  <p>Now, it turns out, that didn't happen.</p>  <p>During a news conference Wednesday, Solicitor General Sylvia Jones told reporters, in response to question by a QP Briefing reporter: "Investigations would not happen at a provincial level or a ministry level."</p>  <p>"They would be the purview and the responsibility of either the local police departments or in some cases, they would refer it to another division, another police operation."</p>  <p>In its news release announcing an investigation last year, the province said one death had been referred to Office of the Chief Coroner for investigation. "Specific critical incidents" in the report were referred to the Ministry of Long-Term Care's inspections branch.</p>  <p><em><strong>WATCH | Jones answers questions about investigation:</strong></em></p>  <div><span><span class="mediaEmbed"><div class="player-placeholder-ui-container  "><div class="player-placeholder-video-ui" title="Ontario's Solicitor General says investigations 'would not happen at a provincial level'" role="button" tabindex="0"><div class="player-placeholder"></div><div class="player-placeholder-ui  "><div class="video-item video-card-overlay" aria-labelledby="1894071363991-metadata-" title="Ontario's Solicitor General says investigations 'would not happen at a provincial level'"><div class="thumbnail-wrapper"><div class="thumbnail-container"><img srcset="

class="video-item-details "><h3 class="video-item-title">Ontario's Solicitor General says investigations 'would not happen at a provincial level'</h3><p class="video-show-name">CBC News Toronto</p><span class="formattedDate video-time-stamp" aria-label="From 1 day ago" aria-hidden="false">1 day ago</span><div class="videoInfoLabel"><div class="videoDuration"><span aria-label="duration 1:10">1:10</span></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div><span class="media-caption">During a news conference Wednesday, Solicitor General Sylvia Jones was asked about the status of the investigation that Ontario said in a news release it had "already begun" last May. Jones says the province would not have conducted an investigation.<!-- --> <!-- -->1:10</span></span></span></div>  <p>In a statement Thursday, a spokesperson for Jones said it was the deputy solicitor general who provided the report to the coroner's office. </p>  <p>"Should there be any criminal concerns during a death investigation, the coroner would bring them to the attention of the police. The Office of the Chief Coroner does not have the authority to lay criminal charges," said spokesperson Stephen Warner.</p>  <p>Speaking in the Legislature on Thursday, Minister of Long-Term Care Merrilee Fullerton said homes were subject investigation by individual inspectors.</p>  <p>"Each home was inspected by two or more inspectors … Had inspectors found potentially criminal conduct, they would have passed that information on to the police."</p>  <h2>'They died when all they needed was water and a wipe down'</h2>  <p>In a letter to Ontario Provincial Police Commissioner Thomas Carrique Thursday, Opposition Leader Andrea Horwath called on the police force to "evaluate" whether instances of lack of water and personal care documented by armed forces and the Long-Term Care COVID-19 Commission "constitute a case for criminal charges."</p>  <p>"As I read of 26 seniors perishing not from COVID-19 but from a lack of water and personal care, my heart broke. I thought we had heard the worst of things, but I was wrong," the NDP's Horwath wrote. "I entrust your force to make a thorough evaluation, and to lay charges where necessary," she said.</p>  <p>The commission, which unveiled its <a href="http://www.ltccommission-commissionsld.ca/report/pdf/Ontarios_Long-Term_Care_COVID-19_Commission_Final_Report.pdf">final 322-page report</a> Friday night, said that by the time the armed forces arrived at the homes identified as most in need of attention, "they found deplorable conditions."</p>  <p>"It was noted by ACCT [augmented civilian care team] that 26 residents died due to dehydration prior to the arrival of the CAF team due to the lack of staff to care for them," the report quotes one member as saying.</p>  <p>"They died when all they needed was 'water and a wipe down.'"</p>  <p><em><strong>WATCH | Long-term care minister responds to report:</strong></em></p>  <div><span><span class="mediaEmbed"><div class="player-placeholder-ui-container  "><div class="player-placeholder-video-ui" title="CBC News asks if Ontario long-term care minister will apologize after COVID-19 Commission releases scathing report" role="button" tabindex="0"><div class="player-placeholder"></div><div class="player-placeholder-ui  "><div class="video-item video-card-overlay" aria-labelledby="1892675651863-metadata-" title="CBC News asks if Ontario long-term care minister will apologize after COVID-19 Commission releases scathing report"><div class="thumbnail-wrapper"><div class="thumbnail-container"><img srcset="

class="video-item-details "><h3 class="video-item-title">CBC News asks if Ontario long-term care minister will apologize after COVID-19 Commission releases scathing report</h3><p class="video-show-name">CBC News Toronto</p><span class="formattedDate video-time-stamp" aria-label="From 4 days ago" aria-hidden="false">4 days ago</span><div class="videoInfoLabel"><div class="videoDuration"><span aria-label="duration 3:25">3:25</span></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div><span class="media-caption">During a press conference Monday, CBC News Queen’s Park reporter Mike Crawley asked Ontario's Minister of Long-term Care Merrilee Fullerton if she or her government would apologize for the crisis in long-term care facilities during the COVID-19 pandemic. This was her response.<!-- --> <!-- -->3:25</span></span></span></div>  <h2>OPP not currently investigating</h2>  <p>But as of Thursday, OPP spokesperson Bill Dickson told CBC News he wasn't aware of any ongoing investigations into deaths at nursing homes in the province related to COVID-19.</p>  <p>Durham Regional Police Services spokesperson George Tudos confirmed an investigation is happening in that region but declined a request for an interview.</p>  <p>"We are reviewing the details of the Ontario's Long-Term Care COVID-9 Commission report released on April 30, 2021 and this remains an ongoing investigation. We don't have anything further to add at this point," he said. </p>  <p>Parkes says she's been told by police an update should be available next week. What that might be, she hasn't been told.</p>  <p>The commission concluded Ontario had no plan to protect long-term care residents amid the pandemic, citing chronic underfunding, staffing shortages and poor oversight.</p>  <div><span><ul class="similarLinks"><li class="similarListItem"><a href="https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/toronto/covid-19-coronavirus-ontario-update-may-26-1.5584665" class="similarLink" flag="" text="Ford faces blowback after military report reveals 'horrific' conditions at Ontario long-term care homes" data-contentid=""><span class="similarLinkText">Ford faces blowback after military report reveals 'horrific' conditions at Ontario long-term care homes</span></a></li></ul></span><span><ul class="similarLinks"><li class="similarListItem"><a href="https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/toronto/long-term-care-pandemic-report-1.6005331" class="similarLink" flag="" text="Ontario's long-term care sector wasn't ready or equipped for COVID-19: report" data-contentid=""><span class="similarLinkText">Ontario's long-term care sector wasn't ready or equipped for COVID-19: report</span></a></li></ul></span><span><ul class="similarLinks"><li class="similarListItem"><a href="https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/toronto/long-term-care-ontario-plan-1.6010266" class="similarLink" flag="" text="Ontario had no plan to address pandemic or protect residents in long-term care, final commission report says" data-contentid=""><span class="similarLinkText">Ontario had no plan to address pandemic or protect residents in long-term care, final commission report says</span></a></li></ul></span></div>  <p>The commissioners also said Dr. David Williams, the province's chief medical officer of health, in particular, was too slow to act on emerging information about COVID-19.</p>  <p>Workers in the long-term care sector were described making personal protective equipment out of "pop bottles and plastic bags" because regular masks were in such short supply.</p>  <p>Earlier Friday, Ford said he welcomed the commission's report, as difficult as it would be to read.</p>  <p>"What happened in our long-term care homes, it was tragic," he said. "And it was terrible. But most of all, it can never be allowed to happen again."</p>  <p><em><strong>WATCH | Ford calls findings 'gut-wrenching':</strong></em></p>  <div><span><span class="mediaEmbed"><div class="player-placeholder-ui-container  "><div class="player-placeholder-video-ui" title="Ontario premier calls military report on long-term care homes 'heartbreaking' and 'gut-wrenching'" role="button" tabindex="0"><div class="player-placeholder"></div><div class="player-placeholder-ui  "><div class="video-item video-card-overlay" aria-labelledby="1742489667898-metadata-" title="Ontario premier calls military report on long-term care homes 'heartbreaking' and 'gut-wrenching'"><div class="thumbnail-wrapper"><div class="thumbnail-container"><img srcset="

class="video-item-details "><h3 class="video-item-title">Ontario premier calls military report on long-term care homes 'heartbreaking' and 'gut-wrenching'</h3><p class="video-show-name">Canada</p><span class="formattedDate video-time-stamp" aria-label="From 12 months ago" aria-hidden="false">12 months ago</span><div class="videoInfoLabel"><div class="videoDuration"><span aria-label="duration 1:26">1:26</span></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div><span class="media-caption">Doug Ford promises accountability and justice after the report describes 'extremely troubling' conditions in the homes.<!-- --> <!-- -->1:26</span></span></span></div>  <p>For now, Parkes waits for accountability in her father's death and those of so many others who died in a place where they expected to receive care.</p>  <p>She's grown tired of the political sound bites, she says, and what she describes a lack of tangible action. </p>  <p>"If you say you're going to do something and you're crying on television about how it affects you, let's see some action. And that's been the problem all along, a lot of words and no action," she said.</p>  <p>Until then, she says: "It's a wound that never gets to close."</p>  <div><span><ul class="similarLinks"><li class="similarListItem"><a href="https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/toronto/orchard-villa-families-hospital-pandemic-1.5614511" class="similarLink" flag="CBC Investigates" text="Nursing home told families hospital wouldn't accept sick residents during pandemic.
